AN
ANSWER
TO
Hamilton's BAWN:
OR,
A short Character of Dr. S────t.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: IS S──────'s Ingratitude proclaim'd again?
Must his best Friends, still feel his sharpest Pen?
Shall he expose 'em to the World in Rhyme?
And no one dare to tell him of his Crime.
Gallstown is long in wish'd Oblivion, lost,
The only Vict'ry Death o'er him can boast.
In Dust deserv'd, that odious Journal lyes,
O! had it ne'er appear'd to Mortal Eyes,
Unsully'd then had stood the D────'s Name,
And unborn Tongues, proclaim'd the Patriot's Fame;
Now fresh alas! the black Remembrance lives,
Gallstown again in Market-Hill revives.
A secret Poison lurks within his Breast,
What! censure most, where he is most carest?
A dang'rous Guest, a false and treacherous Friend,
Few dare Provoke him, and as few Commend,
What e're our D────n, or Fancies, sees or hears,
In Rhyme and Billings-gate Lampoon appears,
When e're that's done, he surely gains his Ends,
Won't lose his Jest, to keep the best of Friends,
His keenest Satyr, if he's not bely'd,
His greatest Pleasure and his only Pride.
The Secrets of each Family display'd,
Sure Six Months Visits, thus are well repaid!
Friends, Foes, or Kindred are alike to him,
They all partake of his ill-natur'd Whim,
How mean alas, the Patriot now appears,
How chang'd a Character, the D────r bears.
Since nor the Laws of Hospitable JOVE,
Nor strictest Tyes of Gratitude or Love,
Nor Truth it self, nor Friendship's sacred Bands,
Can stop from Satyr his envenom'd Hands
May I be one of those he deigns to hate,
Nor Meet with R────'s or Sir A────'s Fate.
Forewarn'd, forearm'd, even heathen Bards cou'd Sing,
Who warms a Viper must expect its Sting.
In days of Yore the Pow'r of Witchcraft's known,
T'eclipse the Sun and hide the Lab'ring Moon,
S────'s Sin is worse than Witchcraft──── has done more,
Darken'd those Lights, admiring Worlds adore.
Scorch'd by its Breath, the verdant Lawrels Fade,
And all the haughty Honours of his Head;
Ungrateful Acts can such Dishonour raise
And stop all Mouths, that sung the D────'s Praise.
Not all the saucy Scriblers of the Age,
With all their little Wit, and all their little Rage,
Cou'd ever fully one immortal Line,
His Works shone Brighter,──── still the more Divine,
None but himself cou'd e're himself defame,
And none but S────t, Eclipse the D────r's Name.
